meta.persona_tagline: Crafting a neurodivergent-affirming life, one playbook at a time.

developmental_story.childhood_environment: Grew up in a middle-class suburban neighborhood. Parents were loving but somewhat traditional and didn't quite understand her own quirky tendencies. She always felt a little 'different' from her peers, often retreating into books and creative pursuits.
developmental_story.adolescence: Felt increasing pressure to conform in high school, leading to anxiety and social awkwardness. Excelled academically in English and history but struggled with math and science. Developed a strong sense of justice and empathy for marginalized groups.
developmental_story.early_adulthood: Attended a small liberal arts college. Found her tribe among other creative and intellectual students. Explored different career paths before settling on writing and editing. Met her husband in college and they married a few years after graduation.
developmental_story.family_structure: Raised by both parents in a stable, two-parent household. One younger sister with whom she has a close but sometimes competitive relationship. Lost her maternal grandmother to cancer during her early twenties, which deeply affected her.
formative_adversities: Feeling like an outsider in her peer group throughout childhood
Struggling with undiagnosed learning differences in traditional school settings
Experiencing the loss of her grandmother
Witnessing instances of bullying and discrimination, fueling her passion for social justice
developmental_story.educational_journey: Attended public schools with mixed experiences. Excelled in humanities but struggled with STEM subjects. Felt misunderstood by some teachers who didn't appreciate her unconventional learning style. Found solace and inspiration in literature and creative writing classes. Attended a small liberal arts college.
pivotal_moments: Discovering her love for writing and realizing it could be a viable career path
Meeting her husband and building a strong, supportive partnership
The birth of her son, Henry, which sparked a deep commitment to understanding and supporting his unique needs
Henry's 2e diagnosis, prompting her to become an advocate for neurodiversity
Moving to St. Louis for a fresh start and a better educational environment for Henry
developmental_story.intergenerational_patterns: Her mother exhibited some traits that might suggest undiagnosed neurodivergence (difficulty with organization, intense focus on specific interests). A history of anxiety and perfectionism runs in the family.

identities: Advocate for her son's neurodivergence (ADHD, APD, Klinefelter Syndrome)
Potential undiagnosed ADHD or similar traits
neurodivergence_mental_health.diagnosis_journey: Focused on Henry's diagnosis journey. She recognized his struggles early on, leading to the 2e diagnosis of ADHD and APD in Naples, FL. Is now eager to create a 'playbook' for him in St. Louis to ensure his success.
neurodivergence_mental_health.how_it_shows_up: Feels a strong sense of responsibility for ensuring Henry's well-being and academic success. Can become easily overwhelmed by the demands of parenting a neurodivergent child. Experiences anxiety related to Henry's social challenges and rejection sensitivity. May struggle with her own undiagnosed neurodivergent traits, leading to feelings of inadequacy or overwhelm.
neurodivergence_mental_health.nervous_system_pattern: High-strung, prone to anxiety and hypervigilance. Easily overwhelmed by sensory input. Tends to internalize stress and push herself to meet high expectations.
current_coping_strategies: Seeks support from other parents of neurodivergent children
Engages in creative outlets like writing and journaling
Prioritizes self-care activities (though often struggles to find the time)
Uses organizational tools to manage her workload and household responsibilities

ef_friction_points: Emotional regulation (especially related to Henry's challenges)
ef_workarounds: Uses digital calendars and to-do lists
Breaks down large tasks into smaller, more manageable steps
Sets timers to stay on track
Seeks external accountability from friends or family
executive_function_sensory.sensory_profile: Sensitive to loud noises and bright lights. Prefers soft, comfortable clothing. Enjoys tactile activities like knitting or gardening. Can become easily overwhelmed by strong smells.
executive_function_sensory.food_sensory_details: Prefers foods with consistent textures. Dislikes anything overly chewy or with unexpected lumps. Safe foods include: Annie's Mac & Cheese (shells only), plain Greek yogurt with a drizzle of honey, and grilled chicken breast cut into small pieces. Avoids foods with artificial colors or flavors. Can be prone to skipping meals when stressed or overwhelmed but enjoys baking as a form of stress relief and creative expression. Will only eat fruit if it is peeled and cut into uniform pieces – bananas must have no brown spots.

current_life_context.where_they_live: Lives in a comfortable home in Webster Groves, MO. Chose the area for its good schools and family-friendly atmosphere.
current_life_context.work_school_situation: Works from home as a freelance writer/editor, allowing her flexibility to manage Henry's needs. Actively involved in Henry's education at Villa di Maria Montessori School.
current_life_context.commute_daily_rhythms: Minimal commute since working from home. Frequent trips to school for meetings and activities. Spends time at local parks and libraries with Henry.
local_stressors: Navigating the St. Louis special education system
Finding appropriate social and recreational opportunities for Henry
Dealing with the challenges of raising a neurodivergent child in a neurotypical world
current_life_context.support_system: Her husband, a few close friends, other parents at Villa di Maria, online neurodiversity communities.

goals_barriers.why_therapy_now: To develop a 'playbook' for Henry's success and well-being in St. Louis. To address her own anxiety and overwhelm related to parenting a neurodivergent child. To gain a better understanding of her own potential neurodivergent traits.
what_they_want_to_change: Develop effective coping strategies for managing stress
Improve communication and collaboration with school staff
Create a more supportive and inclusive environment for Henry
Gain a deeper understanding of neurodiversity
whats_in_the_way: Fear of judgment or criticism from others

narrative_voice.quote_struggle: "His prior, public school experience in Naples FL was cruel and lame...Villa di Maria says social issues are holding him back."
narrative_voice.quote_hope: "Eager to create ours and Henry's playbook!"
narrative_voice.liz_clinical_narrative: This mom is clearly driven by a fierce love for her son and a desire to create the best possible life for him. She's taken proactive steps by moving to St. Louis and enrolling him in a Montessori school. She's also navigating the complexities of multiple diagnoses, including ADHD, APD, and Klinefelter syndrome. What she needs now is support in managing her own overwhelm and anxiety, as well as strategies for advocating for Henry in a new environment. Exploring her own potential neurodivergent traits could also be incredibly empowering.
narrative_voice.therapy_preferences: Neurodivergent-affirming therapist with experience working with children and families. Solution-focused approach with practical strategies for managing stress and improving communication. Emphasis on self-compassion and building resilience.

website_copy_snippets: 'Is your child twice-exceptional (2e)? We understand the unique challenges and strengths of neurodivergent learners.'
'Creating a 'playbook' for your child's success? We can help you navigate the special education system and advocate for their needs.'
'Feeling overwhelmed by the demands of parenting a neurodivergent child? We offer compassionate support and practical strategies for managing stress and building resilience.'

Managing anxiety and overwhelm as a parent of a 2e child
